Chris -

Andy's piece was merely an exploration for possible common ground, something he doesn't actually do very often. The beauty of this is its open-endedness (the author doesn't start with any personal prejudices).

Roberts' piece starts with the premise that "renewable energy" is something we must pursue. Perhaps the reason you like Roberts' writing is because you agree with this premise. The article then purports to frame this as merely a question of "willpower" to achieve some arbitrary "renewables goal", without ever stopping to ask whether achieving a particular benchmark would have a measurable climatic effect.

But it is actually rather silly to argue that one article is "better" than the other. They are not in competition nor are they direct parallels, despite the fact that both are efforts to move the discussion away from perpetual disagreement.

Conflating the effects of delay in a court case about human relationships in society with energy policy initiatives makes about as much sense as having Cypriot Bankers debate the merits of a head scarf ban as it relates to their current economic crisis.

Nevertheless, sometimes "doing nothing" is the best decision.

Before you get more speed, you need to know where you're headed and if it can make the trip. You favor an "accelerate-stop" approach in your climate/energy vehicle. Have you even determined whether your wonder wagon can cross the obstacles ahead, let alone its destination?

Kurt in Switzerland

Andy starts out with a pro Keystone, pro fracking, pro nuclear bias, the issues, and then hopes his friends won't scorn him as a result of his backwardness while he damns them with faint praise for being passionate. He is asking can't we still get along together as friends even though we have disagreements on issues. It is a pretty dumb piece because people can always agree to disagree to get along, but one or both of them are wrong so understanding is not advanced by dropping the topic. Is one engaged in friendship or policy discussion on the opinion page of the NYT?

Roberts is focused on issues and finding ways to acknowledge the valid points on the other side. And, he identifies a good one. I have no problem acknowledging that technology will improve, for example. I'm for more research funding. I suspect that if we are going to draw lines between funding sources and funded efforts, it would be best to fund healthcare and veterans benefits with a surcharge on fossil fuels and energy research with a surcharge on nuclear power rather than some other proposed scheme.

But the largest fastest cost reductions available for renewable energy come from deployment. That is also the fastest path to lower energy costs generally since mined energy resources are already degrading. So, realistically, more research is not all that important to costs over the next 20 or 30 years. Scale is much more important and is needed much more urgently.

Roberts' piece is better because it is focused on issues rather than personal relationships, but I happened to turn on CSPAN radio yesterday afternoon and heard oral arguments in the Proposition 8 case. And, in these arguments there are winners and losers. There are 30,000 or so children in California being raised by gay or lesbian couples who will be harmed if the Supreme Court reverses the lower court finding that Proposition 8 is unconstitutional. Even in a case that is entirely about personal relationships, justice delayed is justice denied, and when the delay, delay, delay argument prevails, great harm results.

So, the thing to think about is how to get more speed. If Andy wants to support the Keystone pipeline, how about if he insist that in be licensed to operate for only five years. Same goes for his support of fracking. A five year window for exploitation and then done. Fossil fuels are, by their very nature, temporary. Climate considerations indicate that they should not even be used at all. So, close the window on them.

Andy, John Gray at New Statesman mag in UK has an article about james lovelock this week, about his new book due out in January 2014, in which Lvoelock says maybe humans can evolve more to solve the problems we face today. Link here:

http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/culture/2013/03/james-lovelock-man-a...

He tells me his next book will consider the possibility that evolution may produce another species, one more capable than human beings have been of coexisting with other life forms on the planet. His intellectual iconoclasm showing no signs of diminishing, Lovelock, in his tenth decade, continues to produce ideas that fundamentally challenge the prevailing world-view. A unique thinker, he has no obvious successor, yet in gaining wide acceptance of the idea that our planet is a self-regulating system, he has had a profound effect on many branches of scientific inquiry. Along with millions of others, I can’t wait to hear the latest thoughts of the scientist who, more than any other alive today, has changed the way we think of the earth and our place on it.

John Gray’s most recent book, “The Silence of Animals”, is published by Allen Lane
